item.title: Off he went to get his guitar
item.trailText: In today’s Fiver: England v Norway, 50 Cent and nightmares from Partick Thistle
item.standFirst: Click here to have the Fiver sent to your inbox every weekday at 5pm, or if your usual copy has stopped arriving
item.body:
A HELL OF A BEATING?

Later on Monday evening, Sone Aluko’s sister – who has a law degree, did you know – will play for England in the last 16 of the Women’s World Cup. Apparently, she also has some team-mates who aren’t Sone Aluko’s sister and don’t have law degrees, but The Fiver has been too busy demanding transfer speculation to be sure.

Law degree or not, Aluko’s manager Mark Sampson is no fool. With his team, ranked sixth in the world, drawn against another, ranked 11th in the world, it makes perfect sense that – rather than acknowledge a nifty chance to reach the quarter-final – he sneak his retaliation in first. So his opponents are not, in fact, “Norway”, but “a Norwegian team whose world ranking probably doesn’t befit the team they’ve got”, and, of course, they are also “physically strong and tactically well organised” – or, put another way, cheats.

Nor is that all. “When a major tournament comes round,” he said, Norway “do more than enough” – though whether this applies to England, and if not, why not, remains unclear. Instead, the game was proclaimed as a “big challenge for this England team”, Sampson’s own involvement in the enterprise suddenly unclear.

But, England being England, the dreaded spot-kicks are also at the forefront of the his mind. “We’re in a good place with penalties,” he said, and penalties later confirmed itself to be a close personal friend and great friend of the squad. As such, planning has been meticulous. “We’ve got a very clear penalty strategy,” Sampson explained, without quite explaining what that means, also asserting that it’ll be the players’ responsibility to score them but his decision who takes them, which seems fair.

England being England, there’s also a strong desire to relieve past failure – in particular, that at Italia ‘90. Accordingly and unsurprisingly, the management are “stoking-evoking those memories with the players”, more than half of whom were aged three or under at the time. Finally, eventually, and at long last, Sampson’s focus turned to himself. “Our team development guru is working hard with me,” he said, “on my breathing techniques and the ability to get myself in the right emotional state to make good decisions.”

And with that, off he went to get his guitar.

LIVE ON BIG WEBSITE TONIGHT

Join Daniel Harris from 10pm BST for MBM coverage of England 1-2 Norway in the Women’s World Cup last 16, before Les Carpenter is on hand for USA! USA!! USA!!! 2-0 Colombia.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

“Me and my man Joe Hart, England and Manchester City goalkeeper. We do it big” – 50 Cent and Joe Hart bond, presumably over a shared experience of having lots of people shoot at them.

RECOMMENDED LISTENING

The latest in our Football Weekly presents … series of documentaries focuses on The Gambler: the story of Jimmy Nielsen.

FIVER LETTERS

“I was reading The Fiver on Thursday when a football (sorry, soccer ball) landed in my back garden (sorry, yard) here in Philadelphia. It was still there on Friday morning, surprisingly unclaimed by any local kids. Closer inspection revealed it had an MLS logo on it. Does this mean that $$$$tevie Mbe has started training with LA Galaxy, practicing those trademark Hollywood balls of his? It certainly wasn’t a corner-kick practice, which wouldn’t have cleared the first training cone” – Justin Kavanagh.

“I understand and almost like the intellectual cynicism of The Fiver’s Stop Football campaign. But it’s not going to work and, more importantly, is probably not as funny as it once might have been. Watching the Copa América just reminds me of the need for a Stop Wrestling At Corners campaign. Apart from defenders and referees, no one associated with football approves of it. Come on. You have about six weeks to use your powers for good” – Tony Thornton.

“See, it’s possible to Stop Football” – letmebefell.

• Send your letters to the.boss@theguardian.com. And if you’ve nothing better to do you can also tweet the Fiver. Today’s winner of our prizeless letter o’the day is: Justin Kavanagh.

JOIN GUARDIAN SOULMATES

Chances are that if you’re reading this tea-timely football email, you’re almost certainly single. But fear not – if you’d like to find companionship or love, sign up here to view profiles of the kind of erudite, sociable and friendly folk who would never normally dream of going out with you. And don’t forget, it’s not the rejection that kills you, it’s the hope.

BITS AND BOBS

Conceptual artist David Shrigley has awoken from a nightmare in which he was chased by an angry, monobrowed Lisa Simpson and converted the consequences of his fevered dream into Partick Thistle’s new mascot. With suitably terrifying consequences.

Danny Ings says he will buck the trend of recent Liverpool strikers by working hard to become a success. “I’ve worked my way up from the bottom, so it is even more special for me,” he honked.

Former cocaine addict Diego Maradona, who recently faced a bill of £33m over unpaid tax in Italy, is set to stand for the Fifa presidency in a bid to clean up world football’s organising body. “I am a candidate,” he reportedly said with a straight face.

There’s a Stjarnan waiting in the way of the Queen’s Celtic’s Big Cup daydream.

Manchester United aim to rule out the possibility of qualifying for the Europa League via the Fair Play League by attempting to sign Sergio Ramos when David De Gea does one to Real Madrid.

Parma have been booted down to Serie D after failing to find a new owner following ongoing cash knack.

Chelsea’s Bernard Traoré has been granted a work permit to play in England, thus clearing the club to send him out on loan to a UK-based side rather than just a European one.

Meanwhile, Ruben Loftus-Cheek is aiming to avoid a season spent in the lower reaches of Dutch football by agreeing that José Mourinho was right to criticise him. “I listened to what the manager said and I wasn’t at the level I need to do better,” he grovelled.

And New York is set to become 174% $exier if reports Andrea Pirlo is set to join Frank Lampard in retirement there are true.

STILL WANT MORE?

Andorra-bound West Ham are back in training already. James Riach popped down to Upton Park, where it’s a summer like no other.

Show off your Big Vase knowledge by matching the qualifiers to the countries they represent in our quiz.

It’s the Sids 2015! And splendid they are too.

There’s no rest for the wicked, hence why the Rumour Mill is still slavishly reprinting gossip and t1ttle-tattle: today, why Bastian Schweinsteiger and Carlos Bacca could be off to Manchester United, plus Charles Aránguiz trousering a move to Manchester City.

Oh, and if it’s your thing … you can follow Big Website on Big Social FaceSpace.

SIGN UP TO THE FIVER

Want your very own copy of our free tea-timely(ish) email sent direct to your inbox? Has your regular copy stopped arriving? Click here to sign up.

A WHOLE GENRE OF MUSIC IN TRIBUTE TO O’TRAP?

cards.title: The Rumour Mill / Austin to Newcastle? Cillesen to Man Utd?
cards.rawTitle: Austin to Newcastle? Cillesen to Man Utd?

item.title: Football transfer rumours: Charlie Austin to Newcastle United?
item.trailText: Jasper Cillesen to Manchester United? | Javier Hernández to Atlético Madrid? | Nani to Fenerbahce? | Roberto Soldado to Galatasaray?
item.standFirst: Today’s tittle-tattle is hoping for a biscuit or a shiny sticker album
item.body:
Suspicions are growing that Manchester United are dragging out negotiations over David De Gea until such time as the Euro implodes and Real Madrid have no usable notes with which to pay for the goalkeeper. That will mean that whole epic saga will have to be aborted and the young Spaniard will be forced to remain at United. Unless, that is, Real find some other token of exchange – and this is where the Daily Mail starts to get excited. “Cristiano Ronaldo, Gareth Bale, Karim Benzema, Luka Modric, Raphael Varane and Dani Carvajal could all come up in negotiations with United,” blurts the giddy organ before adding a disclaimer for the benefit of the light of head: “there are no guarantees that United will get their way.”

Related: Petr Cech closes in on Arsenal move after Chelsea reluctantly pave way

Meanwhile the Daily Mirror reckons that if De Gea eventually move to Real, Louis Van Gaal will replace him with Ajax goalkeeper Jasper Cillessen. You may remember Cillessen as the keeper whom Van Gaal humiliated in the World Cup by hauling him off just before a penalty shootout and replacing him with Tim Krul, all of which raises an interesting issue: if Cillessen joins, what will happen when United concede a penalty at Old Trafford? Ah, yes, silly question.

Elsewhere, Manchester City’s interest in Fabian Delph appears to have cooled, but the club continues to have the hots for Jack Wilshere and, if they fail to land Paul Pogba, will submit an offer for the midfielder that Arsène Wenger cannot refuse. Hmm, something about that last sentence doesn’t feel quite right. Reckon it’s that bit about Arsène Wenger, Earth’s most stubborn man, not being able to refuse an offer. Never underestimate Wenger’s powers of refusal. If the man were not a football manager, he would be a record-breaking fakir, capable of lying on beds of nails for years while refusing to acknowledge any pain. Having said that, Wenger’s concentration may be weak at the moment, as word is he’s deliberating over what to do now that Geoffrey Kondogbia has left Monaco for Inter rather than London. Having failed to take the player from Monaco, perhaps Wenger will take inspiration from them? For the Ligue 1 club are planning to re-invest some of the Kondogbia windfall in William Carvalho. Milan, who had been even more interested in Kondogbia than Arsenal were, are also eyeing up Carvalho, but may plump for Marseille’s Giannelli Imbula or Zenit’s Axel Witsel instead. Lots of name for you there, Arsène.

No excuses. Juventus want to prise Yannick Ferreira Carrasco from Monaco, and there is not much Liverpool can do about that no matter what they think. Meanwhile, New York City are to offer Andrea Pirlo a holiday in the USA.

Newcastle hope that offering Charlie Austin the No9 shirt could be the key incentive that will make the striker choose to go to St James’ Park. And if that doesn’t work, maybe the club will throw in a biscuit or a shiny sticker album, too.

Tottenham hope that holding the door open for Roberto Soldado and handing him his suitcases will help convince the former striker to leave White Hart Lane for Galatasaray. Also Turkey-bound, if Manchester United’s wishes come true, is Nani, in whom Fenerbahce are interested.

Javier Hernández, meanwhile, is on his way back to Madrid, not to Real but to Atlético. Sevilla want Steven Nzonzi and are prepared to help Stoke keep up the ‘z’ quotient on their team-sheet by giving them the Polish midfielder Grzegorz Krychowiak in return.

And Sunderland are chasing Stewart Downing, whom they fear may be tempted to rejoin Middlesbrough instead.

headerImage.caption: Is Charlie Austin set to sneak off to Tyneside? Photograph: Alan Walter/Action Images
headerImage.cleanCaption: Is Charlie Austin set to sneak off to Tyneside?

cards.title: The Agenda / Six of the best continue Wimbledon buildup at Eastbourne
cards.rawTitle: Six of the best continue Wimbledon buildup at Eastbourne

item.title: The Agenda: Six of the best continue Wimbledon build-up at Eastbourne
item.trailText: Six of the world’s top 10 women compete in Eastbourne, early stages of the Champions League are drawn, plus there’s T20 action between England and New Zealand at Old Trafford
item.standFirst: Six of the world’s top 10 women compete in Eastbourne, early stages of the Champions League are drawn, plus there’s T20 action between England and New Zealand at Old Trafford
item.body:
TENNIS TUNE-UP ...

The build-up to Wimbledon continues apace, with the women in action at Eastbourne (from Monday, British Eurosport, BBC), where six of the world’s top 10 prepare for the slam in SW19. Caroline Wozniacki and the reigning Wimbledon champion, Petra Kvitova, are joined in the draw by the defending champion, Madison Keys at the tournament that was first held in 1974. Elsewhere, the BBC celebrate Arthur Ashe in More Than A Champion (BBC2, Friday, 9pm), a documentary looking back at the great player on the 40th anniversary of his win at Wimbledon, with his story told by brother Johnnie and Ilie Nastase. They also begin the first of three programmes remembering some of the truly great finals with the absolute classic between Goran Ivanisevic and Pat Rafter (BBC2, Saturday, 9am) in 2001 – the year Ivanisevic, a three-times beaten finalist and past his best, entered as a wildcard.

CHAMPIONS DRAW ...

Uefa make the draw for the first and second qualifying rounds of the Champions League on Monday, (streaming at uefa.com, 11am) where Celtic (alongside Wales’s The New Saints and Northern Ireland’s Crusaders in the first round draw) will discover who they face in their first match set for 14 or 15 July. Victory over two legs will put them into the third round against clubs such as Ajax, Monaco and Shaktar Donestk before the play-off round, where Manchester United will begin their campaign, which is drawn on 22 August. It is followed by the Europa League draws, where West Ham and Aberdeen will be chosen among the first round qualifiers and Inverness in the second round.

ENGLAND’S BIG BASH ...

The rollercoaster ride of following England continues on Tuesday when they play a single T20 match with New Zealand at Old Trafford (Sky Sports 2, 6pm, Radio 5 Live), their final international before the Ashes begin on 8 July. After a disastrous World Cup, the short-form team has been transformed, not least in their record 350-run chase to beat New Zealand in the fourth ODI (the joint fourth-highest of all time). They had already bettered their best aggregate scoring rate in a five match series by the end of that match with 1,425 over the previous high of 1,399. It is a far cry from Test cricket but going in with a win after such a turnaround in one-day form will not hurt one bit. The Ashes are also considered in a live Flinters and Vaughan roadshow, looking back on cricket’s greatest competition (Thursday, 8pm, Five Live).


MOTORS MAGIC ...

Increasingly popular, the Goodwood Festival of Speed is once again sold out for the Friday and Saturday. Unsurprisingly this year with another stellar lineup, including Nico Rosberg, Felipe Massa, Anthony Davidson, Valentino Rossi and Casey Stoner in action. They are joined by Sir Stirling Moss celebrating his 1955 victory at the Mille Miglia in a Mercedes SLR 300 – and the show will feature seven of the last eight of the cars still in existence. Tickets are available for the Friday but fear not if you cannot make it, the entire event is streamed at goodwood.com/fos, with highlights on MotorsTV (Saturday, 12pm/Sunday 8.30am and Sky F1, Sunday 3pm).

ATHLETICS TEAM TEST ...

Dina Asher-Smith, one of Britain’s brightest sprinting talents competes again onSunday on the second day of the European Team Athletics Championship in Cheboksary, Russia (BBC2, 12.30pm). She has had quite a year, breaking Britain’s 100m record by running an 11.02sec in May and then two weeks later a 22.30 for the 200m, putting her at top of the European rankings. The sprinter, who is 19, runs the latter on Sunday in a chance to test herself against the best – Ukraine’s Nataliya Pohrebnyak, having run 22.98 this season and Russia’s Yekaterina Smirnova, who has recorded 23.04.

cards.title: You are the Umpire / Brendon McCullum

item.title: You are the Umpire: Brendon McCullum
item.trailText: Featuring: Deliberate wides, expensive sunglasses, and a batsman dashing from the nets
item.body:
Click to enlarge, and debate the strip below the line.

John Holder's verdict

1) The issue here is one of protecting the Spirit of Cricket. Is winning really so important to the fielding side that they're willing to contravene that spirit to get a result? The bowling of wides is not against the laws but in this context it clearly seems unfair. I would allow the game to continue beyond the stated finishing time, as long as the batting side and my colleague were happy to do so. I have seen batsmen carry on batting in poor light when it has suited them, and, in this case, I am certain that they would happily continue with the prospect of winning. John Clegg wins the shirt.

2) Out. There's no attempt at foul play here – the ball has struck the fielder and bounced to another without touching the ground. The fielder might very well have sunglasses for medical reasons, even though at that instant he was not wearing them over his eyes. It'd be no different if he was wearing spectacles. Thanks to Ian McGowan.

3) The fielding captain has absolutely no right or authority to complain about what an incoming batsman was doing before going to the crease. How would he feel if his bowlers weren't allowed to warm up beforehand by bowling a few balls to the wicketkeeper, coach or another fielder? What a nonsense. Play on. Thanks to Peter Newell.

Competition: win a T-shirt of your choice

For a chance to win a sporting T-shirt of your choice from the Guardian range send us your questions for You are the Umpire to you.are.the.umpire@observer.co.uk. The best scenario used in each new strip wins a T-shirt; Terms apply. For more on You are the Ref's history, click here.

cards.title: Classic YouTube / Terrible diving, the US Open and a rabbit surfing an avalanche
cards.rawTitle: Terrible diving, the US Open and a rabbit surfing an avalanche

item.title: Terrible diving, the US Open and a rabbit surfing an avalanche
item.trailText: Classic YouTube: Also featuring what it feels like to fly like Superman, a kangaroo versus a cyclist and who would win in a race between American Pharoah and Secretariat
item.standFirst: Also featuring what it feels like to fly like Superman, a kangaroo versus a cyclist and who would win in a race between American Pharoah and Secretariat
item.body:
1) The worst diving this side of a football field.

2) The US Open gets under way this week at Chambers Bay, Washington. You can use this video and this video to bone up on your knowledge of the course before it all gets going. Speaking of the US Open, here are some moments from the tournament’s history. That bout of putting from 2001; Tiger back in 2008 when his game still had some bite (the last time he won a major incidentally) and here he is at his finest in 2000 at Pebble Beach; Tom Watson celebrating like a footballer; and here is a jazzy look back at the final round of the 1968 event at Oak Hill where Lee Trevino won the first of his six major titles.

3) Got 40 minutes to spare? Well why not waste it on the BBC’s 1987-88 season review. By waste on, we, of course, mean thoroughly enjoy.

4) Ouch!

5) Steph Curry got game.

6) For. The. Love. Of. God. Do. Not. Look. Down.

Our favourites from last week’s blog

1) Run rabbit – run rabbit – run! Run! Run! Or surf rabbit – surf rabbit – surf that avalanche!

2) Alex Megos making us all feel rather inferior.

3) Kangaroo v cyclist. (Warning: contains tense buildup!)

4) Ever wondered what it would be like to fly like Superman? Wonder no more.

5) The top 10 moments from week one at the Women’s World Cup, including an absolute belter from Daniela Montoya.

6) Who would win in a race between American Pharoah v Secretariat?

Spotters’ badges: BlackCaeser, RobBarwick, ID0684182, NewYearBaby1981, NappleTale
